children.subject: Also a CS PhD student at Berkeley has a really awesome blog here that I like to read from time to time. You might want to check it out here.
It would be cool for everyone to post things (cause I would like to know too!), but I really like this CMU article and think it is recommended a lot

history.content: I'm not a PhD student or faculty member, but I was a PhD student at Berkeley in a different department for quite a while (not STEM). The coursework that you need to complete for a PhD will depend on your university. In EECS at Cal, you need to do 16 units in a major area and 8 units in each of 2 minor areas and there are some other requirements to fulfill. After that, if you want to take a course in something else, you usually can, though your advisor will want most of your focus to be on your research. If you want to study a language, though, I've seen people do it (I was also a grad advisor for quite a while), or if you want to take a few music classes. The main thing is that your advisor won't want you dawdling around and spending ten years completing your dissertation (don't ask me how long mine took, but I did have two kids along the way).

The details depend on the department but consistently its around 2-3 classes per semester for your first year or two, less classes for your third, and likely no classes 4th and onwards when you are supposed to be entirely focused on your research. I haven't tried to take classes unrelated to my field of research yet, but I can tell you its uncommon. (source: currently a PhD student at Cal not in EECS).

The details depend on the department but consistently its around 2-3 classes per semester for your first or two, less classes for your third, and likely no classes 4th and onwards when you are supposed to be entirely focused on your research. I haven't tried to take classes unrelated to my field of research yet, but I can tell you its uncommon. (source: currently a PhD student at Cal not in EECS).

children.subject:
I didn't see anyone else express this explicitly, but the PhD (especially in STEM) is a research apprenticeship. Even though it has other components, like taking classes and, sometimes, teaching classes (as a TA or lead instructor), research is intended to be and almost always is the primary focus. You are essentially accountable directly to your advisor(s), in an arguably unhealthy way, so you can generally expect anything you do outside of research, especially once you've satisfied your core course and teaching requirements, to be monitored (at best) or intensely scrutinized (at worst). This is even more the case when you don't have backing from external funding (e.g. fellowships). Hypothetical: Imagine you were an advisor who hired a student (this is literally the phrasing used) using your own hard-earned research funds (typically from grants written by other students) and they spent their time taking random useless classes instead of doing the research you were paying them to do!

Anyway, up until about your third year, you have some leeway to take courses that interest you, as long as they can satisfy degree requirements and are vaguely related to your research. The EECS PhD at Cal used to have an "outside minor" in which you were forced to take at least one grad class in an entirely different discipline, but this has been phased out in favor of an "elective requirement", in which you take one >100 level class outside of EECS and and one >100 level class from any department (including EECS).

If you want an idea of what the core curriculum looks like for an EECS PhD, in integrated circuits ("INC"), incoming PhD students are essentially required to take EECS 251+251LA (ASIC lab) and EE 240A in their first semester. Advisors typically caution against taking more than two courses in a semester, in general. In the second semester, these students will then take EE 241B and EE 240B, before doing their oral prelim exam near the beginning of the third semester (it's kind of like an intense technical interview for the right to stay in the PhD program). Preparation for the prelim is the most important thing up until it is passed, which is why students generally take the classes which have content listed as "fair game" for the prelim. You have two tries, or even three, if they like you -- meaning that you are doing good research. Afterward, research becomes unequivocally the most important thing, although it still was very important to begin with. 

If you'd like an idea of what the experience looks like for another program, I have a friend who chose to enroll in Stanford's CS PhD program instead of Cal's. From what I can understand, that program doesn't seem to have any core course requirements (outside of the number of units required for graduation) and doesn't have any prelim requirement either. There are actually breadth requirements, but students are given freedom to select courses as they'd like. There's also a qualifying exam (research presentation + controlled grilling), but Cal has that too. I guess I can understand why my friend chose Stanford. 

tl;dr: The PhD in STEM is about research. Qualified "no" to the second question. Third question: generally 2, ideally fewer, if possible, so that you can put more effort towards research.

history.content: How does PhD in STEM work? Can students still take various classes of interest as they did in undergrad? How many classes can PhD students take each semester? Inputs from PhD students and professors are highly appreciated!
history.subject: What is Grad School (PhD) Like?
